          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

class="metadata Metadata_root__EZem9" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,350<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">You Have an Adversary Problem. Who&#x27;s Targeting You and Why? 
 
Nation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. 
 
During this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:

    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure 
    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft 
    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers
    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat intelligence
</p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read more" 4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Between indicators

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" AboveRecsAd_root__iTmTR"><div class="freestar-ad-container FreestarAdContainer_root__qPPC_" data-testid="freestar-ad-container"><div class="ad-label AdLabel_root__S6xpE"><span>Ad</span></div><div style="min-width:300px;min-height:260px"><div><div class="" id="above-recs-desktop-ad-sm"></div></div></div></div></div><!--$--><div class="rail-recs RailRecommendations_root__zqtZQ"><h2 class="RailRecommendations_title__kt1D2">Recommended</h2><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-0" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R11na7f6:" popovertarget=":R11na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R11na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-espionage-nation-stateaptattacksontherise/53166502"><span class="sr-only">Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:0" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberespionage-nationstateaptattacksontherise-150924184657-lva1-app6892-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberespionage-nationstateaptattacksontherise-150924184657-lva1-app6892-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd1na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd1na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd1na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In the digital age, one of the most effective ways to gather data and information about a potential enemy state is by infiltrating their ranks with malware. This webinar takes a deep drive into advanced persistent threat attacks performed by nation states. We will discuss various actors, government sponsored hackers, such as Duke, Bear, and Panda. Then we will look at malware created, like Regin, Elise, Flame, Equation Group, Babar, OnionDuke, and Dark Hotel.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12na7f6:" popovertarget=":R12na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R12na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/red-team-framework/163164716"><span class="sr-only">Red Team Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Red Team Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/redteamframework-190812114352-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Red Team Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/redteamframework-190812114352-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Red Team Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Red Team Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/JoeGrayCISSPISSMP">👀 Joe Gray</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Presented at the DEFCON27 Red Team Offensive Village on 8/10/19.

From the dawn of technology, adversaries have been present. They have ranged from criminal actors and curious children to - more modernly - nation states and organized crime. As an industry, we started to see value in emulating bad actors and thus the penetration test was born. As time passes, these engagements become less about assessing the true security of the target organization and more about emulating other penetration testers. Furthermore, these tests have evolved into a compliance staple that results in little improvement and increasingly worse emulation of bad actors.

In this presentation, we will provide a framework complementary to the Penetration Testing Execution Standard (PTES). This complementary work, the Red Team Framework (RTF), focuses on the objectives and scoping of adversarial emulation with increased focus on the perspective of the business, their threat models, and business models. The RTF borrows part of the PTES, adding emphasis on detection capabilities as well as purple team engagements. We believe this approach will better assist organizations and their defensive assets in understanding threats and building relevant detections.
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13na7f6:" popovertarget=":R13na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout/adversary-emulation-using-caldera"><span class="sr-only">Adversary Emulation using CALDERA</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Adversary Emulation using CALDERA" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/sec699-sansbrussels-adversaryemulation-190913153030-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Adversary Emulation using CALDERA" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/sec699-sansbrussels-adversaryemulation-190913153030-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Adversary Emulation using CALDERA</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation using CALDERA for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout">Erik Van Buggenhout</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Caldera is an automated adversary emulation tool developed by MITRE that links to the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework. It deploys custom backdoors on target systems to emulate adversary techniques. The tool has a graphical interface to define groups, abilities, adversaries, and operations. Abilities are suites of actions that achieve goals, while adversaries are malicious actors equipped with abilities. Multiple abilities can be grouped in phases, and phases describe the progression of an adversary. Caldera actively attacks targets by deploying backdoors linked to ATT&amp;CK techniques.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R14na7f6:" popovertarget=":R14na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R14na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/how-mitre-attck-helps-security-operations/127515243"><span class="sr-only">How MITRE ATT&amp;CK helps security operations</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="How MITRE ATT&amp;CK helps security operations" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mitre-colaboratory-v4-190108111157-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">How MITRE ATT&amp;CK helps security operations</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/votadlos">Sergey Soldatov</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Talk on Kaspersky lab&#x27;s CoLaboratory: Industrial Cybersecurity Meetup #5 with @HeirhabarovT about several ATT&amp;CK practical use cases.

Video (in Russian): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulUF9Sw2T7s&amp;t=3078

Many thanks to Teymur for great tech dive
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15na7f6:" popovertarget=":R15na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-threat-hunting-panda-security/122396554"><span class="sr-only">What is Threat Hunting? - Panda Security</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="What is Threat Hunting? - Panda Security" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisthreathunting-181108091403-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="What is Threat Hunting? - Panda Security" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisthreathunting-181108091403-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">What is Threat Hunting? - Panda Security</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save What is Threat Hunting? - Panda Security for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/PandaSecurity">Panda Security </a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Threat hunting is a proactive approach to security that involves actively searching networks for threats that evade traditional defenses like firewalls and antivirus. It involves forming hypotheses about potential attacks based on indicators and then validating those hypotheses by searching for related evidence. While threat hunting requires time, skills, and resources that many organizations lack, Panda Security&#x27;s Threat Hunting and Investigation Service (THIS) provides threat hunting as a managed service at no extra cost with their Adaptive Defense 360 platform. THIS continuously monitors endpoints, forms hypotheses about attacks, and validates findings to detect threats that other solutions may miss.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16na7f6:" popovertarget=":R16na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/adversary-emulation-using-caldera-232232038/232232038"><span class="sr-only">Adversary Emulation using CALDERA</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Adversary Emulation using CALDERA" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bruconpresentation-caldera-200418134018-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Adversary Emulation using CALDERA" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bruconpresentation-caldera-200418134018-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Adversary Emulation using CALDERA</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation using CALDERA for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout">Erik Van Buggenhout</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses adversary emulation and the MITRE Caldera tool. It begins with defining adversary emulation and distinguishing it from penetration testing. Various tools for adversary emulation are presented, including METTA, Atomic Red Team, Infection Monkey, and Covenant. The document then focuses on MITRE Caldera, describing what it is, how to set it up, develop custom abilities and plugins for it. It demonstrates running a quick Caldera operation and concludes by discussing how Caldera can be highly customized and help blue teams test techniques to improve security.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17na7f6:" popovertarget=":R17na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/digitoktavianto">Digit Oktavianto</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Slide presentation for Cyber Threat Hunting Workshop at International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Global Cyber Drill 2020 Event.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18na7f6:" popovertarget=":R18na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attck-framework/236612661"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontomitreattck-200328091951-200705113109-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontomitreattck-200328091951-200705113109-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/null0x00">n|u - The Open Security Community</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is a knowledge base of adversary behaviors and tactics collected from real-world observations. It describes how the framework categorizes behaviors using tactics, techniques, and procedures. The framework can be used for threat intelligence, detection and analytics, adversary emulation, and assessment and engineering. The document provides examples of how organizations can map their detection capabilities and data sources to techniques in the framework to improve visibility of attacks. It cautions against misusing the framework as a checklist rather than taking a threat-informed approach.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="sr-only">Introduction to MITRE ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:8" Framework, different use cases, pitfalls to take care about.. Talk was delivered @Null Bangalore and @OWASP Bangalore chapter on 15th February 2019.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19na7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ana7f6:" popovertarget=":R1ana7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ana7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/leveraging-mitre-attck-speaking-the-common-language/150494688"><span class="sr-only">Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/sec599-june2019-sansfire-attck-190619015701-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/sec599-june2019-sansfire-attck-190619015701-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdana7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdana7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdana7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdana7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdana7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout">Erik Van Buggenhout</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK is quickly gaining traction and is becoming an important standard to use to assess the overall cyber security posture of an organization. Tools like ATT&amp;CK Navigator facilitate corporate adoption and allow for a holistic overview on attack techniques and how the organization is preventing and detecting them. Furthermore, many vendors, technologies and open-source initiatives are aligning with ATT&amp;CK. Join Erik Van Buggenhout in this presentation, where he will discuss how MITRE ATT&amp;CK can be leveraged in the organization as part of your overall cyber security program, with a focus on adversary emulation.

Erik Van Buggenhout is the lead author of SANS SEC599 - Defeating Advanced Adversaries - Purple Team Tactics &amp; Kill Chain Defenses. Next to his activities at SANS, Erik is also a co-founder of NVISO, a European cyber security firm with offices in Brussels, Frankfurt and Munich.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ana7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ana7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Protection Beyond Alerting</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:10" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Proactive Threat Hunting: Game-Changing Endpoint Protection Beyond Alerting</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Proactive Threat Hunting: Game-Changing Endpoint Protection Beyond Alerting for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdbna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdbna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdbna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Falcon OverWatch Experts Hunt 24/7 To Stop Incidents Before They Become Breaches

Is your IT security team suffering from alert fatigue? For many organizations, chasing down every security alert can tax an already overburdened IT department, often resulting in a breach that might have been avoided. Adding to this challenge is an increase in sophisticated threats that strike so fast and frequently, traditional methods of investigation and response can’t offer adequate protection. 

A new webcast from CrowdStrike, “Proactive Threat Hunting: Game-Changing Endpoint Protection Above and Beyond Alerting,” discusses why so many organizations are vulnerable to unseen threats and alert fatigue, and why having an approach that is both reactive and proactive is key. You’ll also learn about Falcon OverWatch™, CrowdStrike’s proactive threat hunting service that investigates and responds to threats immediately, dramatically increasing your ability to react before a damaging breach occurs.

Download the webcast slides to learn:

--How constantly reacting to alerts prevents you from getting ahead of the potentially damaging threats designed to bypass standard endpoint security
--Why an approach that includes  proactive threat hunting, sometimes called Managed Detection and Response, is key to increasing protection against new and advanced threats   
--How CrowdStrike Falcon OverWatch can provide 24/7 managed threat hunting, augmenting your security efforts with a team of cyber intrusion detection analysts and investigators who proactively identify and prioritize incidents before they become damaging breaches
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1cna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1cna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1cna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/sounilyu/cyber-defense-matrix-revolutions-252417499"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Defense Matrix: Revolutions</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:11" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Defense Matrix: Revolutions</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdcna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdcna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/sounilyu">Sounil Yu</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Cyber Defense Matrix helps people organize and understand gaps in their overall security program. These slides describe several additional use cases of the Cyber Defense Matrix, including how to map the latest startup vendors and security trends, anticipate gaps, develop program roadmaps, capture metrics, reconcile inventories, improve situational awareness, and create a board-level view of their entire program.

See the 2016 version at: http://bit.ly/cyberdefensematrix
See the 2019 version at: http://bit.ly/cyberdefensematrixreloaded</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1dna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1dna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1dna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mapping-to-mitre-attck-enhancing-operations-through-the-tracking-of-interactive-intrusion-campaignspdf/251521377"><span class="sr-only">Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mappingtomitreattckenhancingoperationsthroughthetrackingofinteractiveintrusioncampaigns-220405233746-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mappingtomitreattckenhancingoperationsthroughthetrackingofinteractiveintrusioncampaigns-220405233746-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Mapping to MITRE ATT&amp;CK: Enhancing Operations Through the Tracking of Interac... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbddna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Jason Wood and Justin Swisher, CrowdStrike

When it comes to understanding and tracking intrusion tradecraft, security teams must have the tools and processes that allow the mapping of hands-on adversary tradecraft. Doing this enables your team to both understand the adversaries and attacks you currently see and observe how these adversaries and attacks evolve over time. This session will explore how a threat hunting team uses MITRE ATT&amp;CK to understand and categorize adversary activity. The team will demonstrate how threat hunters map ATT&amp;CK TTPs by showcasing a recent interactive intrusion against a Linux endpoint and how the framework allowed for granular tracking of tradecraft and enhanced security operations. They will also take a look into the changes in the Linux activity they have observed over time, using the ATT&amp;CK navigator to compare and contrast technique usage. This session will provide insights into how we use MITRE ATT&amp;CK as a powerful resource to track intrusion tradecraft, identify adversary trends, and prepare for attacks of the future.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ena7f6:" popovertarget=":R1ena7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ena7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" for Improving Security Posture in Orga...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Adversary Emulation and Its Importance for Improving Security Posture in Orga..." Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation and Its Importance for Improving Security Posture in Orga... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdena7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdena7f6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdena7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdena7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/digitoktavianto">Digit Oktavianto</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses adversary emulation and its importance for improving security posture. It begins with an introduction to adversary emulation, comparing it to simulation. Adversary emulation involves closely mimicking the actual tactics, techniques, and procedures of a known adversary based on threat intelligence. The document outlines the benefits of adversary emulation, such as helping organizations test their defenses against the latest real-world threats. It also provides guidance on developing an adversary emulation plan, including researching a specific adversary and modeling their behaviors to design scenario-based tests that are executed sequentially.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ena7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ena7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses cyber threat intelligence and strategies for defense. It begins with an introduction to cyber threat intelligence and discusses the cyber attack life cycle model from Lockheed Martin. It then addresses questions to consider regarding cyber threats. The document outlines threat intelligence standards and tools like STIX and TAXII, and discusses challenges with SIEM systems. It proposes architectures that incorporate threat intelligence to provide preventive, detective, and fusion capabilities. The presentation concludes with a discussion of data sources and architectures to support cyber threat analysis.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1fna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1gna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1gna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1gna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-attck-coverage-anyway-breadth-and-depth-analysis-with-atomic-red-team/251521611"><span class="sr-only">What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdgna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdgna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdgna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Brian Donohue, Red Canary

This presentation will highlight the Atomic Red Team project&#x27;s efforts to define and increase the test coverage of MITRE ATT&amp;CK techniques. We&#x27;ll describe the challenges we encountered in defining what &quot;coverage&quot; means in the context of an ATT&amp;CK-based framework, and how to use that definition to improve an open source project that&#x27;s used by a diverse audience of practitioners to satisfy an equally diverse array of needs. The audience will learn how the Atomic Red Team maintainers standardize and categorize atomic tests, perform gap analysis to achieve deep technique-level coverage and broad matrix-level coverage, and quickly fill those gaps with new tests.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1hna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1hna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1hna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/attcking-with-threat-intelligence/107919736"><span class="sr-only">ATT&amp;CKing with Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="ATT&amp;CKing with Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/hopemitre-180729235258-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="ATT&amp;CKing with Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/hopemitre-180729235258-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">ATT&amp;CKing with Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CKing with Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ChristopherKorban">Christopher Korban</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">MITRE’s ATT&amp;CK is a community-driven knowledge base and model for cyber adversary behavior, reflecting the various phases of an adversary’s life cycle and the platforms they are known to target. By scoping the wide breadth of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK matrix to focus initially on the techniques used by threat actors you specifically care about, you can help the defenders create more useful and impactful detections first. Once you start emulating the appropriate threat actors, you can practice your defenses in a scenario that’s more realistic and applicable without the need for an actual intrusion. The speakers are providing a process and a case study of APT3 - a China-based threat group - for how to go from finding threat intelligence, sifting through it for actionable techniques, creating emulation plans, discovering how to emulate different techniques... to actually operating on a network. They are also providing a beginning &quot;cheat sheet&quot; for this actor to give a starting point for red and blue teams to accomplish these techniques in their own environment without the need to build their own tooling.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ina7f6:" popovertarget=":R1ina7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ina7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-mitre-preattck-and-attck-in-cybercrime-education-and-research/241296402"><span class="sr-only">Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/aunshulrege-210113194534-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/aunshulrege-210113194534-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdina7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdina7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdina7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdina7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdina7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour October 2020

By:
Aunshul Rege, Associate Professor, Temple University, @prof_rege

Rachel Bleiman, PhD Student/NSF Graduate Research Assistant, Temple University, @rab1928

This presentation from the MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour session on October 9, 2020, explores the application of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK® and PRE-ATT&amp;CK matrices in cybercrime education and research. Specifically, Rege and Bleiman demonstrate the mapping of the PRE-ATT&amp;CK matrix to social engineering case studies as an experiential learning project in an upper-level cybercrime liberal arts course. It thus allows students to understand the alignment process of threat intelligence to the PRE-ATT&amp;CK framework and also learn about its usefulness/limitations. The talk also discusses the mapping of the ATT&amp;CK matrix, tactics, techniques, software, and groups for two cybercrime datasets created by collating publicly disclosed incidents: (i) critical infrastructure ransomware (CIRW) incidents, and (ii) social engineering (SE) incidents. For the CIRW dataset, 39% of the strains mapped onto the ATT&amp;CK software. For the SE dataset, 49% of the groups and 65% of the techniques map on to the MITRE framework. This helps the researchers identify the framework&#x27;s usefulness/limitations and also helps our datasets connect to richer information that may not otherwise be available in the publicly disclosed incidents.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ina7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ina7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1jna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1jna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1jna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://fr.slideshare.net/mohamedbouhamed/cours-scurit-2asr"><span class="sr-only">Cours sécurité 2_asr</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cours sécurité 2_asr" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/jorgeorchilles">Jorge Orchilles</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Jorge Orchilles is an experienced red team leader who has led offensive security assessments for large financial institutions. The document discusses adversary emulation, which involves the red team emulating realistic adversary tactics, techniques, and procedures to obtain access to an organization. This helps evaluate an organization&#x27;s preparedness against sophisticated attacks. It describes measuring how people, processes, and technologies prevent or detect the red team&#x27;s activities to identify areas for improvement.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1lna7f6:" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using storytelling to increase understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mna7f6:" popover="auto" Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save No Easy Breach DerbyCon 2016 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdnna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdnna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdnna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdnna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdnna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MatthewDunwoody1">Matthew Dunwoody</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Every IR presents unique challenges. But - when an attacker uses PowerShell, WMI, Kerberos attacks, novel persistence mechanisms, seemingly unlimited C2 infrastructure and half-a-dozen rapidly-evolving malware families across a 100k node network to compromise the environment at a rate of 10 systems per day - the cumulative challenges can become overwhelming. This talk will showcase the obstacles overcome during one of the largest and most advanced breaches Mandiant has ever responded to, the novel investigative techniques employed, and the lessons learned that allowed us to help remediate it.

Details a massive intrusion by Russian APT29 (AKA CozyDuke, Cozy Bear)</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1nna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1nna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div [TM]</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM] for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdona7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdona7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdona7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdona7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdona7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/dgsweigert">David Sweigert</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">William F. Crowe presented on the cybersecurity kill chain, which models the stages of a cyber attack based on military doctrine. The model developed by Lockheed Martin includes stages of reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, command and control, and actions on objectives. ISACA and the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security also use similar kill chain models to analyze the process of advanced persistent threats targeting critical systems and data.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ona7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ona7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:24" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">How to set up a Threat Hunting  Team for Active Defense utilizing Cyber Threat Intelligence and how CTI can help a company grow and improve its security posture. </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1pna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1pna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-25" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1qna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1qna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1qna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tracking-noisy-behavior-and-riskbased-alerting-with-attckpdf/251521354"><span class="sr-only">Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:25" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Tracking Noisy Behavior and Risk-Based Alerting with ATT&amp;CK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdqna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdqna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdqna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdqna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdqna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Haylee Mills, Splunk

Having ATT&amp;CK to identify threats, prioritize data sources, and improve security posture has been a huge step forward for our industry, but how do we actualize those insights for better detection and alerting? By shifting to observations of behavior over one-to-one direct alerts, noisy datasets become valuable treasure troves with ATT&amp;CK metadata. Additionally, we can begin to look at detection and threat hunting on behavior instead of users or systems. In this presentation, Haylee will discuss the shift in mindset and the nuts and bolts of detections that leverage this metadata in Splunk, but the concept can be applied with custom tools to any valuable security dataset.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1qna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-26" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1rna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1rna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1rna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/open-source-intelligencefestivalict2014/41794132"><span class="sr-only">Open Source Intelligence (OSINT)</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ICTfestival">festival ICT 2016</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Durante l’intervento verranno presentati i cardini del processo di ricerca delle informazioni mediante la consultazione di fonti di pubblico accesso. Sarà illustrata la teoria alla base di questo processo che prevede l’identificazione delle fonti, la selezione e la valutazione del loro contenuto informativo per arrivare infine all’utilizzo stesso dell’informazione estratta. Nella seconda fase della presentazione verranno mostrati i tool e le metodologie per l’estrazione di informazioni mediante l’analisi di documenti, foto, social network e altre fonti spesso trascurate. In ultimo saranno mostrati sistemi in grado di correlare diverse informazioni provenienti dalle fonti aperte e verranno discussi i relativi scenari di utilizzo nonché le possibili contromisure.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1rna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1rna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-27" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1sna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1sna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1sna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attckcon-20-using-threat-intelligence-to-focus-attck-activities-david-westin-and-andy-kettell-nationwide/193702807"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2.0: Using Threat Intelligence to Focus ATT&amp;CK Activities; Da...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:27" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2.0: Using Threat Intelligence to Focus ATT&amp;CK Activities; Da... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdsna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdsna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdsna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdsna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdsna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses Nationwide&#x27;s experience using threat intelligence to focus their MITRE ATT&amp;CK activities. Their initial broad approach analyzing 240+ techniques at once was unsuccessful. They then prioritized techniques based on threats to the financial sector. This focused their efforts on the 27 most relevant threat actors and the 100+ techniques associated with them. They mapped techniques to the ATT&amp;CK matrix and conducted intelligence research. This intelligence-led approach improved their security posture understanding and enabled prioritized, actionable recommendations. The process is ongoing to constantly evolve their defenses based on the latest intelligence.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1sna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1tna7f6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1tna7f6"></div><div class="separator class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div
