Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":27,"score":0.623927,"slideshowId":"251521611","sourceName":"cm_interact","strippedTitle":"what-is-attck-coverage-anyway-breadth-and-depth-analysis-with-atomic-red-team","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisattckcoverageanyway-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"From ATT\u0026CKcon 3.0\n\nBy Brian Donohue, Red Canary\n\nThis presentation will highlight the Atomic Red Team project's efforts to define and increase the test coverage of MITRE ATT\u0026CK techniques. We'll describe the challenges we encountered in defining what \"coverage\" means in the context of an ATT\u0026CK-based framework, and how to use that definition to improve an open source project that's used by a diverse audience of practitioners to satisfy an equally diverse array of needs. The audience will learn how the Atomic Red Team maintainers standardize and categorize atomic tests, perform gap analysis to achieve deep technique-level coverage and broad matrix-level coverage, and quickly fill those gaps with new tests.","tags":[],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-attck-coverage-anyway-breadth-and-depth-analysis-with-atomic-red-team/251521611","userLogin":"MITREATTACK","userName":"MITRE ATT\u0026CK","viewCount":659},{"algorithmId":"5","displayTitle":"ATT\u0026CKing with Threat Intelligence","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":32,"score":0.621005,"slideshowId":"107919736","sourceName":"cm_interact","strippedTitle":"attcking-with-threat-intelligence","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/hopemitre-180729235258-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"MITRE’s ATT\u0026CK is a community-driven knowledge base and model for cyber adversary behavior, reflecting the various phases of an adversary’s life cycle and the platforms they are known to target. By scoping the wide breadth of the MITRE ATT\u0026CK matrix to focus initially on the techniques used by threat actors you specifically care about, you can help the defenders create more useful and impactful detections first. Once you start emulating the appropriate threat actors, you can practice your defenses in a scenario that’s more realistic and applicable without the need for an actual intrusion. The speakers are providing a process and a case study of APT3 - a China-based threat group - for how to go from finding threat intelligence, sifting through it for actionable techniques, creating emulation plans, discovering how to emulate different techniques... to actually operating on a network. They are also providing a beginning \"cheat sheet\" for this actor to give a starting point for red and blue teams to accomplish these techniques in their own environment without the need to build their own tooling.","tags":[],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/attcking-with-threat-intelligence/107919736","userLogin":"ChristopherKorban","userName":"Christopher Korban","viewCount":6612},{"algorithmId":"5","displayTitle":"Using MITRE PRE-ATTACK and ATTACK in Cybercrime Education and Research","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":16,"score":0.620255,"slideshowId":"241296402","sourceName":"cm_interact","strippedTitle":"using-mitre-preattck-and-attck-in-cybercrime-education-and-research","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/aunshulrege-210113194534-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"From MITRE ATT\u0026CKcon Power Hour October 2020\r\n\r\nBy:\r\nAunshul Rege, Associate Professor, Temple University, @prof_rege\r\n\r\nRachel Bleiman, PhD Student/NSF Graduate Research Assistant, Temple University, @rab1928\r\n\r\nThis presentation from the MITRE ATT\u0026CKcon Power Hour session on October 9, 2020, explores the application of the MITRE ATT\u0026CK® and PRE-ATT\u0026CK matrices in cybercrime education and research. Specifically, Rege and Bleiman demonstrate the mapping of the PRE-ATT\u0026CK matrix to social engineering case studies as an experiential learning project in an upper-level cybercrime liberal arts course. It thus allows students to understand the alignment process of threat intelligence to the PRE-ATT\u0026CK framework and also learn about its usefulness/limitations. The talk also discusses the mapping of the ATT\u0026CK matrix, tactics, techniques, software, and groups for two cybercrime datasets created by collating publicly disclosed incidents: (i) critical infrastructure ransomware (CIRW) incidents, and (ii) social engineering (SE) incidents. For the CIRW dataset, 39% of the strains mapped onto the ATT\u0026CK software. For the SE dataset, 49% of the groups and 65% of the techniques map on to the MITRE framework. This helps the researchers identify the framework's usefulness/limitations and also helps our datasets connect to richer information that may not otherwise be available in the publicly disclosed incidents.","tags":["att\u0026ck","att\u0026ckcon power hour","attackcon power hour"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/using-mitre-preattck-and-attck-in-cybercrime-education-and-research/241296402","userLogin":"attackcon2018","userName":"MITRE - Meanwhile, actors have created a new breed of threat – “Advanced Persistent Manipulators” (APMs), to borrow a term coined by scholar Clint Watts at the Alliance for Securing Democracy in the United States. APMs have learned from APTs’ successes and taken advantage of the developments in information technology with an aim of manipulating information and influencing decision making.\r\nThis presentation will explore Advanced Persistent Manipulator threats through a comparative study with advanced persistent threats. This comparison will examine motives, goals, and tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) related to each. Some may even go so far as to have their 3rd party DFIR partner(s) make statements on their behalf to the effect that the attack would have been successful at most companies. All this is done in an attempt to avoid the dreaded assumption of IT Security negligence on their part. Imagine if the press release stated that the attack might have been thwarted if they implemented processes and controls that were recommended by internal staff years ago.\r\nWhile we will never read that statement, many practitioners are left to wonder what was so unique and advanced about this attack. With this presentation we will present analysis of existing public attacks against traits that are more common in truly advanced attacks. These include but are not limited to the ability to operate undetected, precise targeting, use of non-public zero days and custom payloads, ability to defeat in place security controls, strong operational security, speed and of course overall effectiveness. We will also make clear delineations between what constitutes and advanced attack versus an advanced adversary. The document outlines the key components needed to properly unify next-generation antivirus and endpoint detection and response, including complete visibility of endpoint activity, large-scale analysis capacity, and the ability to derive insights and indicators of attack from collected data. It provides examples of using machine learning techniques like feature selection, dimensionality reduction, and classification on military personnel data and malware samples. While machine learning is effective against most malware, it is not enough on its own as many attacks do not use malware. A comprehensive prevention approach is needed to address the full spectrum of threats.","tags":["next-gen endpoint protection","machine learning","cyber security"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/battling-unknown-malware-with-machine-learning/66689817","userLogin":"CrowdStrike","userName":"CrowdStrike","viewCount":2049},{"algorithmId":"","displayTitle":"Java Journal \u0026 Pyresso: A Python-Based Framework for Debugging Java","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":19,"score":0,"slideshowId":"63429339","sourceName":"MORE_FROM_USER","strippedTitle":"java-journal-pyresso-a-pythonbased-framework-for-debugging-java","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/javajournalpyspresso-160624232225-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Despite the multitude of Java decompilers available, we often have the need to debug or trace malicious or obfuscated Java bytecode. Existing Java debuggers and tracers are mostly targeted towards Java developers, are closed-source, and are not meant to handle malicious or obfuscated targets. We present a new open-source cross-platform framework for debugging Java, written completely in Python, designed specifically for reverse engineering. Key points include:\n\n- The malware uses inline code obfuscation and encrypted strings to hide its functionality and communication domains. Researchers were able to deobfuscate the code and decrypt the strings to analyze the malware. \n\n- Clues in decrypted strings suggest the malware author is Romani, including references to Romani singers in template strings. \n\n- The malware generates domain names by concatenating two randomly selected words from a dictionary and appending \".net\". However, the selection of Tor-friendly software for Windows is sub-par at best. \r\n\r\nWant to anonymously browse the web? You’re stuck with Firefox, and don’t even think about trying to anonymously use Flash. Want to dynamically analyze malware without letting the C2 server know your home IP address? You’re outta luck. Want to anonymously use any program that doesn’t natively support SOCKS or HTTP proxying? Not gonna happen. \r\n\r\nWhile some solutions currently exist for generically rerouting traffic through Tor, these solutions either don’t support Windows, or can be circumvented by malware, or require an additional network gateway device. \r\n\r\nMissed the live session at Black Hat USA 2013? acts)\n\u003e Real-world enterprise use cases: enterprise co-pilots, DevOps automation, multi-agent orchestration, and decision-making support\n\u003e Key risks based on the OWASP Agentic AI Threat RAMIREZ","viewCount":67},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"Refactoring meta-rauc-community: Cleaner Code, Better Maintenance, More Machines","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":32,"score":0,"slideshowId":"279228002","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"refactoring-meta-rauc-community-cleaner-code-better-maintenance-more-machines","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/leon-anavi-rauc-er2025-250517062920-74cfa038-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"RAUC is a widely used open-source solution for robust and secure software updates on embedded Linux devices. In 2020, the Yocto/OpenEmbedded layer meta-rauc-community was created to provide demo RAUC integrations for a variety of popular development boards. The goal was to support the embedded Linux community by offering practical, working examples of RAUC in action - helping developers get started quickly.\nSince its inception, the layer has tracked and supported the Long Term Support (LTS) releases of the Yocto Project, including Dunfell (April 2020), Kirkstone (April 2022), and Scarthgap (April 2024), alongside active development in the main branch. Structured as a collection of layers tailored to different machine configurations, meta-rauc-community has delivered demo integrations for a wide variety of boards, utilizing their respective BSP layers. These include widely used platforms such as the Raspberry Pi, NXP i.MX6 and i.MX8, Rockchip, Allwinner, STM32MP, and NVIDIA Tegra.\nFive years into the project, a significant refactoring effort was launched to address increasing duplication and divergence in the layer’s codebase. The new direction involves consolidating shared logic into a dedicated meta-rauc-community base layer, which will serve as the foundation for all supported machines. This centralization reduces redundancy, simplifies maintenance, and ensures a more sustainable development process.\nThe ongoing work, currently taking place in the main branch, targets readiness for the upcoming Yocto Project release codenamed Wrynose (expected in 2026). Beyond reducing technical debt, the refactoring will introduce unified testing procedures and streamlined porting guidelines. These enhancements are designed to improve overall consistency across supported hardware platforms and make it easier for contributors and users to extend RAUC support to new machines.\nThe community's input is highly valued: What best practices should be promoted? What features or improvements would you like to see in meta-rauc-community in the long term? Let’s start a discussion on how this layer can become even more helpful, maintainable, and future-ready - together.\n\n","tags":["linux","rauc","yocto"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/refactoring-meta-rauc-community-cleaner-code-better-maintenance-more-machines/279228002","userLogin":"leonanavi","userName":"Leon Anavi","viewCount":53},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"MULTI-STAKEHOLDER CONSULTATION PROGRAM On Implementation of DNF 2.0 and Way F...","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":18,"score":0,"slideshowId":"279173480","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"multi-stakeholder-consultation-program-on-implementation-of-dnf-2-0-and-way-forward","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/dnf2-250516045043-c28843bf-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Join us for the Multi-Stakeholder Consultation Program on the Implementation of Digital Nepal Framework (DNF) 2.0 and the Way Forward, a high-level workshop designed to foster inclusive dialogue, strategic collaboration, and actionable insights among key ICT stakeholders in Nepal. It offers tools for development, deployment, and orchestration.\n\nComplementing this, the Agent2Agent (A2A) protocol is an open standard by Google that enables these AI agents, even if from different developers or frameworks, to communicate and collaborate effectively. A2A allows agents to discover each other's capabilities and work together on tasks.\n\nIn essence, ADK helps create the agents, and A2A provides the common language for these connected agents to interact and form more powerful, interoperable AI solutions.","tags":["google","google adk","ai agents"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/building-connected-agents-an-overview-of-google-s-adk-and-a2a-protocol/279360326","userLogin":"SureshPeiris","userName":"Suresh Peiris","viewCount":74},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"AI and Gender: Decoding the Sociological Impact","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":12,"score":0,"slideshowId":"279357343","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"ai-and-gender-decoding-the-sociological-impact","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/ai-and-gender-decoding-the-sociological-impact-250519204829-a67c4dd7-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Exploring the Intersection of Technology and Society. The presentation includes two live demos: one that books flights by checking my calendar, and another showcasing a tiny local visual language model for efficient multimodal tasks.\n\nKey themes include:\n✅ When to use single-agent vs. multi-agent setups\n✅ How to define agent roles, memory, and coordination\n✅ Using small/local models for performance and cost control\n✅ Building scalable, reusable agent architectures\n✅ Why personal use cases are the best way to learn before deploying to the enterprise","tags":["ai","artificialintelligence","aiagents"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/harmonizing-multi-agent-intelligence-open-data-science-conference-gary-arora-chief-architect/279195720","userLogin":"GaryArora","userName":"Gary Arora","viewCount":115}]},"slideDimensions":{"height":540,"width":959},"sectionSummaries":[{"summaryList":"[\n    {\n        \"slides\": [\n            1,\n            2\n        ],\n        \"topic\": \"Understanding Adversary Problems\",\n        \"cover\": \"Introduction to adversary problems in cybersecurity.
